questions.question: Question 1: Which of the following statements is false about fibroids?

options.a: More common in Asians than African-Americans
options.d: Does not usually increase in size during pregnancy

questions.explanation:
Fibroids are more common in African-American women. Uterine fibroids are benign, smooth muscle tumors present in the uterine musculature. They are 
most commonly seen during reproductive years. Estrogen and progesterone promote the 
development of fibroids. Option B: Hypoestrogenism occurs in smokers, therefore smoking is protective for fibroids. Option C: Estrogen exposure is increased in nulliparous women, therefore fibroids are more 
common. Increased parity is protective for fibroids. Option D: Most fibroids do not increase in size during pregnancy. Pregnancy can have an 
unpredictable effect on fibroids based on individual genetic and environmental factors.

questions.question: Question 2: Which of the following genes is not associated with leiomyomas?
questions.explanation:
MLH1 gene is not associated with leiomyomas. Its mutation leads to endometrial carcinoma. MED12 and HMGA2 are the most common genes associated with leiomyomas. Other genes 
involved are COL4A5-A6 and the gene for fumarate hydratase (FH). FH gene mutation leads to 
hereditary leiomyomatosis and renal cell cancer (HLRCC) syndrome.

questions.question: Question 3: Leiomyomas create a hyperestrogenic state by all of these mechanisms except:

options.a: Cells contain a greater density of estrogen receptors
options.c: Have higher levels of cytochrome P450 aromatase

questions.explanation:
Leiomyomas convert less estradiol to the weaker estrone. 624 
Sold by @itachibot Leiomyomas create a hyperestrogenic environment, which is a requisite for their growth and 
maintenance. The hyperestrogenic environment is created by the following mechanisms: • Compared to normal myometrium, leiomyoma cells contain a greater density of estrogen 
receptors, which results in greater estradiol binding. • These tumors convert less estradiol to the weaker estrone. • There are higher levels of cytochrome P450 aromatase in leiomyomas compared with normal 
myocytes. This specific enzyme catalyzes the conversion of androgens to estrogen.

questions.question:
Question 4: Initially, all fibroids are  
.
questions.explanation:
Initially, all fibroids are intramural. Fibroids develop in the myometrium, as 
intramural/interstitial and then branch out to form the other types. Classification of fibroids based on anatomical location: • Body (corporeal) fibroids- • Interstitial/intramural fibroids: They are the most common (75%). • Subserosal fibroids: They are the least common (10%). Interstitial fibroids grow outwards to 
form subserous fibroids and are covered by the peritoneum. These include wandering or parasitic 
fibroids and broad ligament fibroids. • Submucous fibroids: Interstitial fibroid grows inwards towards the uterine cavity. It is the most 
symptomatic type. • Cervical fibroids

questions.question:
Question 5: A 55-year-old lady comes with abnormal uterine bleeding. A hysterectomy was performed and 
the following specimen was retrieved. What is the diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
625 
Sold by @itachibot The given cut section image showing multiple nodules, well-circumscribed, firm, and 
white-greyish with a whorled appearance is Leiomyoma (Fibroid). Leiomyoma is the most common benign and the most common pelvic tumor in females and is 
more common in obese females(hyper-estrogenism). They are mostly asymptomatic and the most 
common symptom is menorrhagia. Leiomyomas can also present with bleeding areas, cystic degeneration, and calcifications. The 
uterine cavity is compressed. The image below different types of uterine fibroids classified according to their locations: Sub-mucous fibroids are the most symptomatic type and intra-mural fibroids are the most 
common type of uterine fibroids. Other options: Option B: Endometrial cancer presents as a polypoid mass protruding into the uterine cavity or as 
a diffuse thickening of the endometrium. The cut surface may appear white to yellow and may 
show areas of necrosis or hemorrhage. Option C: Endometrial polyps are usually small and may be single or multiple. Grossly, they 
appear as soft, red to pink, often pedunculated (attached by a stalk) masses protruding into the 
uterine cavity. It presents with heavy cyclic or intermenstrual bleeding, or without complaints as 
an incidental finding on imaging. Estrogen and progesterone have been implicated in the growth 
of endometrial polyps, and higher receptor levels are seen compared with the normal 
endometrium. Option D: In Adenomyosis (Endometriosis interna), the uterus may appear bulky and 
symmetrically enlarged. On the cut section, the myometrium may appear thickened and may show 
tiny cystic spaces filled with old blood (chocolate cysts). The preferred treatment is hysterectomy. 
Localised excision or levonorgestrel IUCD is tried in younger women. The image below shows both the gross and histologic appearances of adenomyosis: 626 
Sold by @itachibot

questions.question:
Question 6: Which of the following symptoms would you not expect in a patient diagnosed with uterine 
fibroids?
questions.explanation:
Menouria and hypomenorrhea are not seen in patients with uterine fibroids. Menouria occurs due 
to vesicouterine fistulas. Hypomenorrhea is seen in Asherman's syndrome and due to OCP use. Fibroids present with the following clinical features: • Menstrual symptoms such as: • Menstrual irregularities - heavy menstrual bleeding/menorrhagia which is the most common 
symptom, polymenorrhoea, and intermenstrual bleeding (metrorrhagia) • Dysmenorrhea • Postmenopausal bleeding • Abdominal pain • Abdominal distension, mass abdomen • Vaginal discharge • Infertility • Recurrent abortions • Pressure symptoms such as: • Urinary retention • Increased frequency of urination • Constipation • Broad ligament fibroids can cause compression of the ureter leading to hydronephrosis or 
hydroureter. 627 
Sold by @itachibot

questions.question:
Question 7: 615 
Sold by @itachibot A patient presented with intermenstrual bleeding for the past 6 months. Which of the 
following types of fibroid is usually associated with this symptom?
questions.explanation:
Intermenstrual bleeding is common with submucous fibroids. Metrorrhagia or intermenstrual 
bleeding refers to bleeding that occurs during the middle of the menstrual cycle. Metrorrhagia in a woman over 40 years warrants a dilatation and curettage procedure to rule out 
endometrial cancer. This is associated with fibroids in 3% of cases. Polymenorrhoea in a patient with fibroids occurs when she has polycystic ovaries or pelvic 
inflammatory disease (PID). Progressive menorrhagia is seen in intramural and submucous myoma due to increased 
vascularity, endometrial hyperplasia, and an enlarged uterine cavity. Note: Further the distance of the fibroid from the cavity, lesser is the possibility of menorrhagia. 
For this reason, subserous and pedunculated fibroids do not cause menorrhagia.

questions.question:
Question 8: A 46-year-old woman presented with heavy menstrual bleeding and dysmenorrhea. You 
suspect a diagnosis of submucous uterine fibroids. Which of the following investigations will 
help you confirm this?
questions.explanation:
Investigations required to identify submucous fibroids include: • USG - most commonly done. Transvaginal USG is useful to assess the location, dimension, and 
associated adnexal pathology. • MRI gives better soft tissue details but is not routinely done • Saline infusion sonography and hysteroscopy - help to visualise submucous fibroid more clearly • Laparoscopy - If uterus <12 weeks size and associated pelvic pain and infertility and to detect 
pelvic endometriosis and tubal pathology. • Uterine curettage – A bump is felt in submucous fibroid during endometrial curettage. Dilatation 
and curettage is done in patients presenting with postmenopausal bleeding. • Hysterosalpingography – A filling defect is seen. CT abdomen is not very useful for the identification of submucous fibroids. These cannot be 
visualised on colposcopy either. The image below shows the ultrasonographic appearance of a submucous fibroid (asterisk): 628 
Sold by @itachibot The image given below shows hysteroscopic view of a submucous fibroid:

questions.question:
Question 9: An adnexal mass seen on ultrasound in a 38-year-old woman was diagnosed to be a 
secondary broad ligament fibroid. Which of the following is true about the same?

options.a: It arises from the broad ligament
options.b: The uterine vessels always lie medial to it
options.c: The ureter always lies lateral to it
options.d: It is also known as true broad ligament fibroid

questions.explanation:
The ureter and uterine vessels lie lateral to a secondary broad ligament fibroid. There are 2 types of broad ligament fibroids: Primary broad ligament fibroid: • It is also known as true broad ligament fibroid. • The arise from: • Uterosacral ligament • Round ligament 629 
Sold by @itachibot • Tissues in the broad ligament • Relations: • The uterine vessels lie medial to it. • The ureter is usually beneath the fibroid. However, it can be present anywhere in relation to it. Secondary broad ligament fibroid: • It is also known as false broad ligament fibroid. • They arise from the lateral wall of the uterus or cervix, but grow laterally, between the two layers 
of the broad ligament. • Relations - the uterine vessels and ureter lie lateral to it.

questions.question: Question 10: Which of the following is incorrect about fibroids?

options.b: Hyaline degeneration begins at the centre

questions.explanation:
Fibroid calcification begins at the periphery and spreads inwards along the vessels. A typical myoma is a well-circumscribed tumor with a pseudo-capsule and firm in consistency. Its 
cut surface has a whorled appearance. The vessels that supply blood to the tumor lie in the capsule and send radial branches into the 
tumor. Therefore, the central portion of the tumour receives the least blood supply, and 
degeneration is noticeable early in this part of the tumour. However, fibroid calcification begins at 
the periphery. The image given below show the gross appearance of fibroids. The below image shows the histological appearance of fibroids. 630 
Sold by @itachibot

questions.question:
Question 11: A patient with a history of miscarriage underwent a myomectomy. The specimen is shown 
below. Where does the degenerative change shown here begin from?
questions.explanation:
The given specimen shows red degeneration of fibroid. Degeneration is most likely to start from 
the centre of the fibroid. In a fibroid, centre of the tumor is the least vascular part and hence degeneration is more 
common here. The only exception is calcareous degeneration where phosphates and carbonates of 
lime are deposited in the periphery along the course of the vessels.

questions.question:
Question 12: A 44-year-old woman presenting with acute abdominal pain had previously been diagnosed 
with uterine fibroids. Which of the following complications is most unlikely to have occurred 
here?
questions.explanation:
Hyaline degeneration of fibroids is unlikely here as it is usually painless and presents as an 
abdominal mass causing distension and heaviness. Acute pain in fibroids is seen in the case of: • Fibroid torsion • Hemorrhage into the fibroid • Red degeneration • Sarcomatous change - seen in postmenopausal women.

questions.question:
Question 13: A primigravida presented with severe abdominal pain and fever at 28 weeks of gestation. 
Ultrasound reveals a healthy fetus in utero and a large submucosal fibroid with multiple, 617 
Sold by @itachibot hyperechoic areas within. Blood investigations reveal leukocytosis and a raised ESR. What is 
the diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
The given case scenario is suggestive of red degeneration of fibroid. It is most common during the second trimester of pregnancy. The gross appearance is described 
as follows: 631 
Sold by @itachibot • Fishy odor • Thrombosis of subcapsular vessels and vessels within the fibroid • Purplish-red color due to diffusion of blood pigments from the thrombosed vessels. Red degeneration presents with acute abdominal pain, fever and, vomiting. Investigations reveal 
leukocytosis and a raised ESR. On radiology, the hemorrhagic areas appear hyperechoic within 
the fibroid. The image given below shows the MRI appearance of red degeneration of fibroids Option B: Torsion of subserous pedunculated fibroid presents with severe pain abdomen, but 
fever and leukocytosis are absent. Option C: Infection is more common in puerperium and presents with blood-stained vaginal 
discharge. Option D: Sarcomatous changes occur very rarely, and are unlikely in patients <40 years of age. 
They are more commonly seen in post-menopausal women.

questions.question:
Question 14: A 34-year old woman with a history of fibroids presented with 1.5 months of amenorrhea. 
UPT is positive. Which of the following complications will you not expect in this patient?
questions.explanation:
Fetal malformations have not been recorded to occur due to fibroids. Pregnancy complications due to fibroids are: • Increased risk of abortion or miscarriage • Preterm labor • Abnormal presentation • Fibroid degeneration (Red degenaration) • Accidental hemorrhage • Dystocic labor 632 
Sold by @itachibot • Postpartum hemorrhage • Puerperal sepsis • Uterine inversion

questions.question: Question 15: Which of the following changes are not seen in fibroids?
questions.explanation: Squamous metaplasia is not seen in fibroid.

questions.question:
Question 16: CT pelvis of a woman with fibroids is shown below. Which type of degeneration is seen here? 618 
Sold by @itachibot
questions.explanation:
The given image shows womb-stone appearance on CT, suggestive of calcific degeneration of 
fibroid. These are also called calcareous myomas and are seen in old patients with long-standing myomas. 
This occurs due to the deposition calcium phosphates and calcium carbonates in the periphery of 
the fibroid, along the course of the vessels. It is easily visualized on radiography.

questions.question: Question 17: What is the least common secondary change seen in fibroids?
questions.explanation:
Sarcomatous change is the least common secondary change in fibroids. Its incidence is <0.5%. Sarcomatous change leads to the development of malignant leiomyosarcomas. This is seen in 
postmenopausal women and is rare in women <40 years of age. Intramural and submucous 
tumors have a higher potential for sarcomatous change than subserous tumors. Its gross appearance is described as follows: • Soft consistency • Yellowish-grey • Hemorrhagic spots seen Radiology shows dark, irregular areas and air levels within the fibroid. These are indicative of 
sarcomatous change. The image given below shows the CT appearance of a large fibroid that has undergone 
sarcomatous change. The image on the right shows a fluid level within the tumor. 633 
Sold by @itachibot

questions.question:
Question 18: A 46-year-old woman presents with a lower abdominal mass for the past 2 years. She had 
undergone uterine artery embolisation for fibroids 5 years ago. Ultrasound showed a 
homogeneous mass near the uterine fundus. On exploratory laparotomy, the mass was 
observed to be attached to the greater omentum and it was excised. Histopathology of the 
mass is shown below. What is your diagnosis? 619 
Sold by @itachibot
questions.explanation:
The given case scenario is suggestive of a parasitic fibroid. The given histopathological image 
shows interlacing bundles of uniform spindle-shaped smooth muscle cells with blunted nuclei that 
are characteristic of a fibroid. A parasitic fibroid or a wandering fibroid gets cut off from its uterine origin and derives its blood 
supply from the vessels of the organ it is attached to. Thus, it can continue to grow in spite of 
uterine artery embolisation. It is managed by complete resection. Option A: Pedunculated fibroids have a pedicle with which they're attached to the myometrium. Option C: Leiomyosarcoma commonly presents in postmenopausal women with sudden increase 
in size and postmenopausal bleeding. It would show nuclear atypia on histology. Option D: Disseminated intraperitoneal leiomyomatosis involves large areas of sub peritoneal 
surfaces. It is seen during pregnancy and while on oral contraceptives.

questions.question:
Question 19: A pregnant woman with a fibroid uterus develops severe acute pain abdomen at 28 weeks of 
gestation. There is no history of fever and the WBC count is 8000 cells/mL. The most likely 
diagnosis is:
questions.explanation:
The given scenario of severe acute abdominal pain without fever/leucocytosis in a pregnant 
woman with a fibroid is suggestive of fibroid torsion. The incidence of fibroid in pregnancy is about 1 in 1,000. Due to increased vascularity in 
pregnancy, the fibroid increases in size and becomes softer. The torsion is seen in the subserous 
pedunculated fibroid where the venous return is blocked at its site of attachment in the uterus. 
This leads to severe acute abdominal pain. Due to the complication being more local than 
systemic, fever or leucocytosis are generally not seen. A transvaginal ultrasonogram is immediately done to detect the position and size of the fibroid, 
which is followed by laparotomic myomectomy as a part of emergency surgical management. 634 
Sold by @itachibot Other options: Option A: Red degeneration of fibroid is seen commonly in the second half of pregnancy or 
puerperium. It is due to a hemorrhagic infarction of the tissue and typically presents as acute focal 
abdominal pain with fever and leucocytosis. Treatment is usually conservative with bed rest, 
analgesics, and sedatives. Option B: Preterm labor is where the labor starts before 37 completed weeks. It is characterized by 
true labor pain. The abdominal pain is slowly increasing in intensity and duration and is also 
accompanied by show (expulsion of the cervical mucus plug). There are intervals between 
episodes of contractions where the patient doesn't complain of abdominal pain.

questions.question:
Question 20: A primigravida at 24 weeks presents to you for a routine antenatal checkup. On ultrasound, 
you incidentally note the presence of two 3x3cm submucosal fibroids. How will you manage 
this case?
questions.explanation:
The given case scenario is suggestive of an uncomplicated fibroid during pregnancy. These are 
managed conservatively. Surgery is only indicated in the case of a pedunculated fibroid undergoes torsion.

questions.question:
Question 21: A 40-year-old woman presented with menorrhagia and increased frequency of micturition. 
Ultrasound abdomen shows the following picture. Which of the following drugs is not used in 
the management of her condition?
questions.explanation:
The given case scenario and ultrasound image showing a well-defined, heterogeneous hypoechoic 
mass are suggestive of a uterine fibroid. Misoprostol does not help to reduce the size of the fibroid 
and so is not recommended for its management. Medical management of fibroids helps to reduce their size. The drugs used in therapy are as 
follows: • Antiprogesterone – Mifepristone / RU-486 • GnRH analogs • Agonists – goserelin, leuprorelin, nafarelin, buserelin • Antagonists – cetrorelix, ganirelix • Levonorgestrel releasing intrauterine system • Selective progesterone receptor modulator (SPRM) – Asoprisnil • Danazol - usually not used due to androgenic side effects.

questions.question:
Question 22: A patient diagnosed with leiomyoma was prescribed an intranasal spray to manage her 
disease. Which of the following drugs is it unlikely to contain?
questions.explanation:
The nasal spray is unlikely to contain histrelin, as it is only available as a subcutaneous implant. GnRH analogues are used to treat leiomyomas. Intranasal preparations are available for 
leuprolide, nafarelin, and buserelin. However, leuprolide has maximal action as an intramuscular 
injection. 635 
Sold by @itachibot GnRH analogue therapy in fibroids is given as follows: • Leuprolide acetate (Lupron) - given intramuscularly. It is also available as an intranasal spray, 
but isn't commonly used. • Goserelin (Zoladex) - subcutaneous depot implant • Triptorelin (Trelstar) IM injection • Nafarelin and buserelin - given as intranasal sprays bd • Histrelin - available as subcutaneous implants.

questions.question:
Question 23: 621 
Sold by @itachibot A pregnant woman was diagnosed with red degeneration of fibroid at 26 weeks of gestation. 
What is the next step in her management?
questions.explanation:
Red degeneration of fibroid is managed conservatively with bed rest and analgesics. It is most common during the second trimester of pregnancy. Red degeneration presents with 
acute abdominal pain, fever and, vomiting. Investigations reveal leukocytosis and a raised ESR. 
On radiology, the hemorrhagic areas appear hyperechoic within the fibroid.

questions.question:
Question 24: A 32-year-old woman presented with anemia due to heavy menstrual bleeding in spite of 
medical management of fibroids. She was posted for a myomectomy as she wanted to have 
children in the future. Which of the following is not an indication for this procedure?
questions.explanation: Red degeneration is not an indication of myomectomy. It is conservatively managed. Myomectomy is indicated in the following: • Symptoms compromising the quality of life such as: • Heavy menstrual bleeding, causing anemia • Pelvic pain • Urinary symptoms and ureteric obstruction. • The patient is unwilling for hysterectomy • The patient wishes to preserve childbearing function • Fibroids causing infertility

questions.question: Question 25: Which of the following modalities is not used for the treatment of leiomyomas?
questions.explanation:
Ultrasound-guided transcervical metroplasty is not used in the treatment of leiomyomas. It is 
used for the resection of the uterine septum. Uterine artery embolization/Uterine fibroid embolization (UAE/UFE) is an angiographic 
interventional procedure that delivers polyvinyl alcohol (PVA) microspheres or other synthetic 
particulate emboli into both uterine arteries thus producing ischemia and necrosis. The vessels 
serving leiomyomas have a larger caliber, hence these microspheres are preferentially directed to 
the tumors, thus sparing the surrounding myometrium. 636 
Sold by @itachibot Nd:YAG myolysis is laparoscopic myolysis performed with an Nd:YAG laser. It causes coagulation 
of a subserous fibroid. The below image shows uterine artery embolization. Magnetic Resonance guided Focused Ultrasound (MRgFUS) is also called MR-guided 
high-intensity focused ultrasound (MR-HIFU). Ultrasound energy is focused to heat and incite coagulative necrosis in selected myomas. 
Concurrent MR imaging enables precise targeting and provides real-time tissue temperature 
feedback to limit surrounding thermal injury. The given image shows MRgFUS.

questions.question:
Question 26: The following procedure was planned for a patient with uterine fibroids. Which of the 
following statements is false about this procedure? 622 
Sold by @itachibot
questions.explanation:
637 
Sold by @itachibot The given image shows uterine artery embolization (UAE). UAE cannot be done in nulliparous 
women as embolization of ovarian vessels can cause ovarian failure and premature menopause. Under local sedation, bilateral UAE is approached through percutaneous femoral catheterization. 
Embolization is done by releasing polyvinyl alcohol (PVA), gel foam particles or metal coils into 
the uterine artery. 638 
Sold by @itachibot Endometriosis and Adenomyosis
